summary: Desmoid tumor, also known as aggressive fibromatosis, is a rare, locally aggressive and invasive type of fibromatosis related to sarcoma. It arises from fibroblasts and does not metastasize, but can cause pain, loss of function, and life-threatening problems by compressing vital organs. Most cases are sporadic, but some are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP). The condition is characterized by a variable and often unpredictable clinical course, with a tendency for recurrence.
risk_factors: History of previous abdominal surgery (for FAP patients and general recurrence)
CTNNB1 mutation 45F (associated with high risk of recurrence)
symptoms: Compression of vital organs (e.g., intestines, kidneys, lungs, blood vessels, nerves)
treatments: Wnt pathway inhibitors (e.g., E7386, tegavivint, ipafricept, investigational)
Oral tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., imatinib, sorafenib, pazopanib, sunitinib)
subtypes: Desmoid tumor of the head and neck
Desmoid tumor of the chest wall
Desmoid tumor of the pelvic cavity
Desmoid tumor of upper extremity and shoulder girdle
Desmoid tumor of lower extremity and pelvic girdle
